Subject: Everyday stories
Title: Áán átin mwáán we pikinik
Author: William, Alvios
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This booklet is a narrative telling the story of a picnic at South Field. It follows a group of students as they take part in fun activities, face small challenges, and work together as a team. The story is brought to life through engaging illustrations that support the scenes and emotions described. Throughout the narrative, readers see moments of joy, cooperation, and problem-solving. In the end, the story carries a meaningful lesson, highlighting values such as friendship, teamwork, and perseverance.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF downloaded by iREi (2025) from UH Scholar Space (https://hdl.handle.net/10125/42190).
DOCUMENT FILENAME: PALM - Printed [Trial version] - CHUUKESE - Áán átin mwáán we Pikinik
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: PALM - Printed [Trial version] - CHUUKESE - Áán átin mwáán we Pikinik

Subject: Place and community
Title: Acn sesr un pa Kosrae
Author: Sabino, Johnny
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Kosraean and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This book introduces Kosrae, an island in the Federated States of Micronesia, through a concise description of its geography, culture, local customs, and natural resources. Aimed at young local readers, the book includes simple illustrations that help enhance understanding and is well-suited for anyone interested in learning more about Kosrae.

Subject: Cultural stories
Title: Angaangan non famini
Author: William, Alvios
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This booklet tells the story of Chiro's family life. It explains how Chiro's parents share responsibilities at home. The mother and father each have their own tasks, and Chiro and his two sisters also have their own duties. Chiro’s family life is not only about cleaning the house, farming even cooks together, they also enjoy spending their free time on vacations. This book is suitable for children because it shows an example of an ideal family and teaches good values.

While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Woleaian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Subject: Health and nutrition
Title: Iyeele mele yaashe science buuku
Author: Rosario, Marcus
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Woleaian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025) by extracting and formatting content from the PALM CD-ROM (1999), a collection of educational materials in Carolinian, Chamorro, Chuukese, Kosraen, Marshallese, Palauan, Pohnpeian, Samoan, Ulithian, Woleaian, and Yapese languages.T

Written entirely in Yapese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025). Digitized from a hard copy courtesy of the COM-FSM Library, with special thanks to librarian Scarlett Lebehn. Scanning conducted by Belinda Welles in Pohnpei in September 2025.

Author: Ehsa, Hanover I.
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Pohnpeian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025) by extracting and formatting content from the PALM CD-ROM (1999), a collection of educational materials in Carolinian, Chamorro, Chuukese, Kosraen, Marshallese, Palauan, Pohnpeian, Samoan, Ulithian, Woleaian, and Yapese languages.T
DOCUMENT FILENAME: PALM CD - Pohnpeian - Kisin mpwel me men sopohla
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: PALM CD - Pohnpeian - Kisin mpwel me men sopohla

Subject: Everyday stories
Title: Kofkof uh pwacr
Author: Likiaksa, Ned
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Kosraean and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Written entirely in Pohnpeian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Written entirely in Kosraean and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF downloaded by iREi (2025) from UH Scholar Space (https://hdl.handle.net/10125/42190).

Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
This story appears in the collection titled “Fiyoang kowe si dipli” in the Ulithian language. It may also appear as a standalone work in other versions and languages.
From “Legends of Micronesia”.
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Ulithian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF extracted by iREi (2025) from an omnibus volume downloaded from UH Scholar Space (https://hdl.handle.net/10125/42190).
DOCUMENT FILENAME: PALM - Printed - ULITHIAN - Fiyoang kowe si dipli - Mala Matamwoal Maey
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: PALM - Printed - ULITHIAN - Fiyoang kowe si dipli - Mala Matamwoal Maey

While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Yapese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025). Digitized from a hard copy courtesy of the Micronesian Seminar Library, with special thanks to librarian Melba Veloso. Scanning conducted by Aden Suwel and Koh Ming Wei in Yap in March 2025.

Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
Adapted from an original story by Patsy Layne.
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Written entirely in Pohnpeian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025) by extracting and formatting content from the PALM CD-ROM (1999), a collection of educational materials in Carolinian, Chamorro, Chuukese, Kosraen, Marshallese, Palauan, Pohnpeian, Samoan, Ulithian, Woleaian, and Yapese languages.T

While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Pohnpeian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Subject: Living things and environment
Title: Pihda esehla mehkot
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Pohnpeian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This educational text in Pohnpeian explains the life cycle of fish, the food chain (predator and prey relationships), and the concept of symbiosis in the ocean. It discusses how different fish species depend on each other and their environment to survive, and concludes with a warning about the dangers of overfishing and the importance of conserving marine life to prevent species from dying out.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025). Digitized from a hard copy courtesy of the COM-FSM Library, with special thanks to librarian Bruce E. Robery. DSLR-based scanning conducted by Danko Taboroši in Pohnpei from 2015 to 2019.

THUMBNAIL FILENAME: PALM - Printed [Trial version] - POHNPEIAN - Pihda Esehla Mehkot; POHNPEI-level6

In printed versions, this story is combined with another story under the titles “Perien en Seri Silimen” or “Pwutak Perien Silimen”. It may also appear as a standalone work in other versions and languages.
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Pohnpeian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Subject: Living things and environment
Title: Sancher aa kaee eew nesen
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This educational text in Chuukese explains the life cycle of fish, the food chain (predator and prey relationships), and the concept of symbiosis in the ocean. It discusses how different fish species depend on each other and their environment to survive, and concludes with a warning about the dangers of overfishing and the importance of conserving marine life to prevent species from dying out.

Written entirely in Ulithian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025). Digitized from a hard copy courtesy of the COM-FSM Library, with special thanks to librarian Scarlett Lebehn. Scanning conducted by Belinda Welles in Pohnpei in September 2025.

Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Woleaian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Subject: Living things and environment
Title: Siibaang sa mwooach madaf
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Ulithian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This educational text in Ulithian explains the life cycle of fish, the food chain (predator and prey relationships), and the concept of symbiosis in the ocean. It discusses how different fish species depend on each other and their environment to survive, and concludes with a warning about the dangers of overfishing and the importance of conserving marine life to prevent species from dying out.

While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Ulithian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Ulithian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.

Title: Toet mo irel matamatal paapaal faliuyach [book 2]
Author: Langal, Isaac
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Ulithian and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025). Digitized from a hard copy courtesy of the COM-FSM Library, with special thanks to librarian Scarlett Lebehn. Scanning conducted by Belinda Welles in Pohnpei in September 2025.
